titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Wilhelm Bock (1897-1972) was born in Poland, and served in the German artillery and air force in World War I. In the 1930s, he emigrated to the United States, becoming a citizen sometime after 1946. He was trained in mechanical engineering and owned a small manufacturing firm in North Wales, Pennsylvania. He took up the study of Triassic fossils, and joined the Academy as a research associate in the former Department of Geology and Paleontology. In the early 1960s organized The Geological Research Foundation, apparently in his home, to provide advice to local communities about matters concerning water supply, but the organization never became active. Remnants of Bock's collection of fossils are at the Academy, though a large part of his collection is now lost.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence, photographs, notes and drawings of Wilhelm Bock. Photographs are black and white images of plant and animal fossils. Correspondence relates to his research and his collection of specimens. The collection also includes a list of items in Bock's fossil collection and a map of Stafford County, Virginia.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
